Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Phone Call Passport-A Smartphone Application to Allow Free Phone Calls
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent surveys indicate that more than 50 % of the US population today owns one or more smart-phones. Across the globe this trend is only increasing. For example, in India, one of the most significant smart-phone markets, the number of owners today is reported to be 330M. Currently international calls are expensive, whether through a cellular network or other services like Skype, resulting in prohibitive costs for many individuals, such as teenagers or students or high volume users who would use more than the allowed limit to call landlines and/or mobile phones. As an alternative, the research team has developed a smartphone application (Phone Call Passport) which allows users abroad and at home to call or text message any number for free using unused minutes available at peer phones.

The proposed application is based on the idea that performing phone calls from mobile phones to landline and mobile numbers through the cellular network is still extremely expensive when performed from abroad. Phone Call Passport (PCP) program uses unused minutes available at other phones within the PCP peer network. In particular, users that provide free phone calls and text messages receive a reward for the services they offer to users wanting to call and/or text abroad. The reward can be in the form of coupons, free minutes or preferences when they wish to use peer minutes to make calls themselves. This project creates a radical new avenue to exploit free minutes at phones. With the dramatic increase in smart-phone markets and VoIP technologies, there is a significant commercial impact. The team will design user-friendly cross platforms apps to enable Phone Call Passport, extensively test and validate it, and create opportunities for dissemination and commercialization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is the design, implementation, and deployment of Phone Call Passport - a smartphone application that will allow users to perform phone calls to any number (abroad and at home) for free using unused minutes available at peer phones. A critical additional goal is to validate the hypothesis with the help of extensive customer discovery and understand the process of commercializing the product by leveraging intensive training and coaching provided by I-Corps mentors. As part of this project, we have conducted around 120 customer interviews. Of these, a vast majority were in person (face-to-face) interviews. We have also conducted interviews with people residing not only in the US, but across the globe including citizens in countries like India, Middle East, China, Taiwan and more, when these subjects were visiting the US. We developed a complete business model canvas as a result of our interviews, and developed a clear idea of challenges and opportunities in commercializing our technologies.

Intellectual Merit: Our proposed technique (Phone Call Passport) allows phone call and text messages to any kind of recipient device for free. The intellectual merit of our idea is as follows. In many countries, mobile telephony providers offer free calls and text messages provided the user subscribes a 3G/4G Internet plan. However, many users do not use the full amount of free phone calls and texts, and renew their plans monthly without taking full advantage of such offers. For instance with AT&T’s roll over plan that is currently in place, users can accrue minutes that they have un-used. It is certain that many users continue to accrue such minutes without ever using them resulting in wasted resources at their disposal. Phone Call Passport leverages these unused free minutes and text messages to allow users to perform phone calls and text services to non-internet numbers for free. In particular, users that provide free phone calls and text messages (which we call Dialers) receive a reward for the services they offer to users wanting to call and/or text abroad (which we call Callers). The reward can be in the form of coupons, free minutes or preferences when they wish to use peer minutes to make calls themselves. This mechanism allows tremendous savings. The innovation lies in designing the entire system in a manner that is transparent to users and minimally disruptive to ISPs and Telecom companies, while still sustaining the quality of phone calls, and creating innovative and practical incentives for subjects.

Broader impact: The broader impact is significant. Calling abroad, and even using extra minutes that allowed is very expensive. Phone Call Passport will alleviate a huge burden from our society. We also expect improved social communication, especially over voice, to bridge society together, and demonstrate new avenues for crowdsourcing as well. Students were also trained while working on this project in both VOIP technologies, Communications Networking, and Business skills development. Students trained are expected to be innovative in their future careers in the technology field.
